bibl.title: Letter from J.L. Byrd to Henry Rose Carter, July 12, 1923

div1.p: Byrd tells Carter that long mosquito flights did not cause a great increase in malaria in Colon. He thinks the reopening of the Canal Zone to agriculturists will result in increased malaria. He sends Carter his paper detailing anti-malarial operations.

div1.head: Letter from J.L. Byrd to Henry Rose Carter, July 12, 1923
div1.opener:
Flights
C Byrd Colon
Infecting & for Oviposia
THE PANAMA CANAL
CANAL ZONE
HEALTH DEPARTMENT
Health Office - Cristobal-Colon
July 12, 1923.
IN REPLY REFER TO FILE
Dr. H. R. Carter,
Assistant Surgeon General,
2121 California St. N. W.
Washington, D. C.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I received your letter of June 20th a few days ago, and in
reply to your inquiry I wish to refer you to the inclosed paper, en-
titled, “A Resume of the Anti-Malarial Operations at Cristobal-Colon
from 1917 to 1922, Inclusive.”

Under ordinary conditions the long flights did not cause any
great increase in the malarial incidence in Colon. However, you will
note that during the labor strike in 1919, when about 2,000 native
strikebreakers were brought into Colon, we had an epidemic of malaria
in Cristobal-Colon. The anopheles flights at this time were from a
distance of one mile or more.

The Canal Zone has been reopened to agriculturists and small
shacks and native villages are springing up all over the Canal Zone.
Such buildings are not permitted within one mile of the sanitated cities.
The question is, “Will the re-population of the Zone greatly increase
our malarial rate?”

Personally I believe that it will cause some increase, for
some of the flight mosquitoes will be already infected before they
reach the cities and in this case only one bite will be necessary to
produce a case of malaria.
div1.closer:
Yours very truly, J. L. BYRD Health Officer,
Cristobal-Colon,
Cristobal, C. Z.
